acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 3 from its 48h-EC50 = 22.7 ppm for Crustacea (Daphnia magna) (SIDS, 2007).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 496 mg/kg for rabbits (ACGIH (2001)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, a LC50 value was 19.7 mg/L (4-hour equivalence: >4.9 mg/L) for rats (IUCLID (2000)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on no mortality in rats exposed to saturated vapours of the substance (4650 ppm: 14.01 mg/L) for 8-hour (ACGIH (2001)), the LC0 (8h) was >14.01 mg/L/8h (LC0 (4h): 19.9 mg/L = approximately 20 mg/L/4h). The substance was classified as "Not classified" in JIS Classification (correspond to Category 5 or "Not classified" in GHS classification).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on LD50 values of 2600 mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and 4260 mg/kg (ACGIH (2001)) for rats, the substance was classified into "Not classified" in JIS Classification (correspond to Category 5 in GHS classification).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Although there is a report that forestomach precancerous lesions such as papilloma and hyperplasia were observed in a rat long-term (life-time) feeding test (PATTY (5th, 2001)), classification was not possible due to lack of sufficient data.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Not classified since the toxicity is mitigated in environmental water by buffer action though it is considered to be a factor of toxicity that water solution become strongly acidic.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Information is available that the substance corrodes metals (ICSC (J) (1997), however, no data by the designated test methods are available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Flash point 53 degC (closed-cup) (ICSC (J) (1997)) is >=23 degC and <=60 degC.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative results in a rat dominant lethal test by oral administration (in vivo heritable germ cell mutagenicity test) (IUCLID (2000)), a Chinese hamster micronucleus test by intraperitoneal administration (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and a rat bone marrow chromosomal aberration test by oral administration (IUCLID (2000)) (in vivo somatic cell mutagenicity tests), the substance was classified as "Not classified". As relevant information, from in vitro mutagenicity tests, there are reports of a negative Ames test (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and a negative human WI38 cell chromosomal aberration test (IUCLID (2000)). In addition, for calcium propionate, there are reports of a negative rat dominant lethal test and a negative rat bone marrow chromosomal aberration test (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

hazardous_to_ozone.rationale: This substance is not listed in Annexes to the Montreal Protocol.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance contains oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine) in the molecule which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 485 degC (ICSC (J) (1997)) exceeding 70 degC.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: There is a report that no effects on maternal animals or fetal survival and no increase in the number of fetal abnormalities were seen when the substance was fed to pregnant rats, mice, hamsters, or rabbits (PATTY (5th, 2001)). However, classification was not possible since there are no data for effects on sexual function and fertility by exposure before mating.

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. Although there is a case report of mild cough and asthmatic reaction in a worker who was acutely exposed to the substance (ACGIH (2001)), this information is not sufficient as evidence for classification.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Since the substance caused severe injury, graded 9 on a scale of 10 in a rabbit test (HSDB (2006)) and there is a result of "corrosive" in another test (IUCLID (2000)), the substance was classified into Category 1. As relevant information, the substance is classified as corrosive to skin.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on reports that application to rabbit skin produced a severe response (PATTY (5th, 2001), tissue necrosis (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001)) and corrosion (IUCLID (2000)), the substance was classified into Category 1. As relevant information, the substance is classified into R34 in EU classification.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: No data available. The calcium and sodium salts of the substance are reported to be "not sensitizing" in a guinea pig maximization test (IUCLID (2000)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In feeding tests in rats (for 3 months) and dogs (for 100 days), the substance mainly caused effects by site of contact, changes of the mucosa of the forestomach (acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and proliferation of the epithelium) were observed in rats and epithelial hyperplasia in the esophagus was observed in dogs at the high dose group. Other severe toxic findings were not noted. NOAELs are reported to be dietary concentrations of 2.5% (correspond to approximately 1250 mg/kg/day) in rats and 1% (correspond to 600 - 696 mg/kg/day) in dogs (SIDS (2008)). Since the NOAELs exceed the upper limit of the guidance value range for Category 2, the substance corresponds to "Not classified" with oral exposure. However, classification was not possible due to lack of data with other exposure routes.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Inhaling the substance can irritate the nose, throat and lungs causing coughing, wheezing and/or shortness of breath in humans (HSFS (2001)). Irritation of the respiratory system was observed in rats following inhalation exposure for 4-hour (HSDB (2000)). Based on the data, the substance was classified into Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation).
